Award.AwardTitle: Transforming STEM Education on Cape Cod and Region

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will build on well-documented evidence-based teaching practices to improve STEM education at this college through extensive professional development and support for STEM faculty members. The focus of the project is on redesigning eight gateway courses. The project will offer similar professional development and support to K-12 STEM teachers from eight partner school districts. These activities are in support of the ultimate goal of developing partnerships with business, higher education, and research institutions regionally to improve STEM education outcomes in its service area and to consolidate the regional STEM network. This connected approach to institutional transformation is novel. Within the local pipeline of STEM interested students, it has the promise of smoothing the transition for students from high school (where they will be better prepared for college) into highly effective lower division courses in college.

The project will assess the impact of these project on student success in STEM courses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This planning grant from NSF was focused on improving STEM education outcomes at Cape Cod Community College (CCCC) and at regional K-12 educational partners through four main areas of activity.

The first focus area was to improve STEM education outcomes at Cape Cod Community College in eight Math, Chemistry, Computer Science and Biology gateway courses. This project provided CCCC faculty with coaching and support from specialists to incorporate effective, evidence-based pedagogical techniques into their educational practices, including inquiry and problem-based learning, group projects with real-world application, co-ops and field research, and field-based activities. Exposure to these practices occurred through a series of targeted professional development workshops led by experienced facilitators with the aim of bringing together core STEM faculty to learn through the process of sharing information and experiences with the group over time. This method of professional development provided faculty with the training and peer support to effectively incorporate more active, problem-based learning methods into their gateway courses.

The second area of activity was to improve STEM education and college readiness outcomes for regional K-12 partners. This project has helped to shape STEM education regionally and facilitate the development of a community of practice among K-12 STEM educators by offering extensive evidence-based professional development and by initiating a Teacher-in-Residence program.  The Teacher-in-Residence program paired K-12 educators with STEM-rich institutions (such as museums, nature centers, engineering firms, manufacturing sites and research laboratories) in a two-week externship in which educators and a host site collaborated to produce grade-specific curriculum material based on the work of the organization and interest of the educator. Finished curriculum units that tie in science and engineering on Cape Cod have been posted to the Cape Cod Regional STEM Network website for public dissemination (capecodstemnetwork.org).

A third area of focus was to continue to develop the Cape Cod Regional STEM Network (CCRSN). The CCRSN brings together educators, school districts, business and industry partners, and community members who share a commitment to inspiring and supporting young people's interest and achievement in STEM learning and careers. Regular meetings, design challenges, community events, website and promotional materials, and teacher professional development have all coalesced to yield growth in the STEM Network's membership and engagement as well as a more robust regional STEM education pipeline. The work of the CCRSN continues to facilitate the development of a vibrant STEM learning community and position CCCC as a hub linking K-12 districts to industry segments and 4-year institutions.

The final goal for this project was to plan for the scaling up and sustainability of the CCRSN. During the course of this planning grant, the CCRSN was selected to be part of the STEM Learning Ecosystems Initiative that forms a national community of practice with expert coaching and support form leaders such as superintendents, scientists, and industry partners. Involvement in the STEM Learning Ecosystems Initiative has provided CCRSN with access to mentoring, models for scaling effective STEM education programs regionally and nationally, and technical resources for developing an ecosystems approach to STEM education in our region. These activities have brought value to the Network by facilitating a strategic planning process and strengthening both service delivery and engagement among Network stakeholders. The Network's participation in this initiative has also provided increased access to national funding resources and opportunities.

 

 


Last Modified: 11/29/2018
Modified by: Eric Arsznov

The first focus area was to improve STEM education outcomes at Cape Cod Community College in eight Math, Chemistry, Computer Science and Biology gateway courses. This project provided CCCC faculty with coaching and support from specialists to incorporate effective, evidence-based pedagogical techniques into their educational practices, including inquiry and problem-based learning, group projects with real-world application, co-ops and field research, and field-based activities. Exposure to these practices occurred through a series of targeted professional development workshops led by experienced facilitators with the aim of bringing together core STEM faculty to learn through the process of sharing information and experiences with the group over time. This method of professional development provided faculty with the training and peer support to effectively incorporate more active, problem-based learning methods into their gateway courses. This project has helped to shape STEM education regionally and facilitate the development of a community of practice among K-12 STEM educators by offering extensive evidence-based professional development and by initiating a Teacher-in-Residence program. The Teacher-in-Residence program paired K-12 educators with STEM-rich institutions (such as museums, nature centers, engineering firms, manufacturing sites and research laboratories) in a two-week externship in which educators and a host site collaborated to produce grade-specific curriculum material based on the work of the organization and interest of the educator. The CCRSN brings together educators, school districts, business and industry partners, and community members who share a commitment to inspiring and supporting young people's interest and achievement in STEM learning and careers. Regular meetings, design challenges, community events, website and promotional materials, and teacher professional development have all coalesced to yield growth in the STEM Network's membership and engagement as well as a more robust regional STEM education pipeline. The work of the CCRSN continues to facilitate the development of a vibrant STEM learning community and position CCCC as a hub linking K-12 districts to industry segments and 4-year institutions. During the course of this planning grant, the CCRSN was selected to be part of the STEM Learning Ecosystems Initiative that forms a national community of practice with expert coaching and support form leaders such as superintendents, scientists, and industry partners. Involvement in the STEM Learning Ecosystems Initiative has provided CCRSN with access to mentoring, models for scaling effective STEM education programs regionally and nationally, and technical resources for developing an ecosystems approach to STEM education in our region. These activities have brought value to the Network by facilitating a strategic planning process and strengthening both service delivery and engagement among Network stakeholders.
